prompt: Emilio Estevez is a renowned American actor and filmmaker, born in 1962. Please write a short biography of Emilio Estevez.
response:
Emilio Estevez was born on May 12, 1962, in Staten Island, New York, to actor Martin Sheen and his wife, Janet Templeton. He is the eldest of four siblings, including actors Charlie Sheen, Ramón Estevez, and Renée Estevez.

Growing up in a family of actors, Emilio was exposed to the entertainment industry from a young age. He made his acting debut at the age of 10 in his father's 1973 film "The Execution of Private Slovik." Throughout his childhood, he appeared in various stage productions and short films, honing his craft under the guidance of his parents.

After graduating from the University of Southern California's School of Theater, Emilio began his professional acting career in the late 1980s. He gained recognition for his roles in the iconic 1980s coming-of-age films "The Breakfast Club" (1985) and "St. Elmo's Fire" (1985), as well as the hit comedy "Young Guns" (1988).

In the 1990s, Emilio continued to establish himself as a talented actor, appearing in films such as "Men at Work" (1990), "Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation" (1994), and "The Mighty" (1998). He also began to explore his passion for directing, helming the independent film "Bobby" (2006), which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.

In addition to his work in film, Emilio has maintained a strong presence in television, guest-starring in popular shows like "The West Wing" and "ER." He has also continued to work in theater, both on and off Broadway.

Throughout his career, Emilio has been recognized for his contributions to the entertainment industry, including a Screen Actors Guild Award nomination for his work on "Bobby." Despite his success, Emilio remains humble and committed to his craft, continuing to take on a wide range of roles and projects that showcase his versatility and talent.

In the 1990s, Estevez continued to appear in a range of films, including "St. Elmo's Fire" (1985), "Young Guns" (1988), and "Mistress" (1992). He also began to branch out into directing, making his debut with the film "Men with Guns" in 1997.

Estevez has continued to work in both acting and directing throughout his career, with notable roles in films such as "The Mighty Ducks" (1992) and "Angels in the Outfield" (1994). He has also directed several films, including "Bobby" (2006), a drama about the life and death of Robert F. Kennedy, and "The Public" (2018), a drama about a group of homeless people who take over a public library.

Estevez has been recognized for his work with several award nominations, including a Golden Globe nomination for his performance in "Bobby." He has also been recognized for his directing work, including a DGA Award nomination for his direction of "The Public."

Estevez is married to singer-songwriter and artist, Sonja Magdevski, and they have two children together. He is known for his commitment to his craft and his dedication to telling stories that explore the human condition.

Estevez's early years were marked by a love for sports, particularly soccer. He was a talented midfielder and played for the University of Southern California's (USC) soccer team. However, after suffering an injury that ended his athletic career, Emilio turned his attention to acting.

The film's success catapulted Estevez to stardom, and he went on to appear in several notable films throughout the 1980s and 1990s, including "St. Elmo's Fire", "Young Guns", "Men at Work", and "The Mighty Ducks". His impressive range and versatility earned him critical acclaim and numerous award nominations.

In addition to acting, Emilio has also explored his creative side through writing and directing. He made his directorial debut with the 2006 film "Bobby", a biographical drama about the life of Robert F. Kennedy. The film earned Estevez an Independent Spirit Award nomination for Best Director.

Estevez has been married to singer-songwriter Sonja Magdevski since 2006, and they have two children together. Despite his success, Emilio remains humble and true to his artistic roots, often citing his father's influence and guidance as a driving force behind his career.
